repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport Technical
            Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Santiago Urban Transport
            Technical Assistance Project for Chile were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: in
            upper-middle-income countries, especially the ones with high
            technical capacity, Bank involvement in transport
            constitutes a true two-way investment. Accompanying the
            whole reform process, from its design to the solution of the
            launch problems, was highly instructive and the lessons
            learned from this experience are greatly valued among other
            Bank clients. In upper-middle-income countries, access to
            international experiences and flexibility are more valued
            than the Bank's financial resources. To successfully
            implement a Bank project in a country like Chile, the
            Bank's financial resources constitute little incentive
            and other elements must be in place. It is difficult to
            design a good results framework for a Technical Assistance
            Loan (TAL) or an institutional strengthening component. A
            TAL that accompanies a Development Policy Loan (DPL) needs
            careful planning.

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport Technical
            Assistance Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Santiago Urban
            Transport Technical Assistance Project for Chile is to
            support the Borrower in achieving an efficient and
            sustainable urban transport system for Metropolitan
            Santiago. The restructuring includes: (i) cancelling
            US$1,440,439 of the loan amount because some project
            activities have been and will still be fully or partially
            financed with local funds; (ii) revising the withdrawal
            schedule to reflect the partial loan cancellation and
            reallocate funds between expenditure categories; and (iii)
            revising the project costs and the financing plan accordingly.

            Technical Assistance Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Chile - Santiago Urban Transport Technical
            Assistance Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project Development Objective (PDOs)
            of the Santiago Urban Transport Technical Assistance Project
            is to provide a loan to support the Trans-Santiago
            Metropolitan to achieve a sustainable urban transport system
            and sustainable development for the Province of Santiago.
            The potential environmental impacts will be small in scale,
            probably causing minimal or zero adverse impacts because the
            work will occur in existing roads and in the Metropolitan
            Region of Santiago. Possible negative environmental impacts
            include: altered water course, altered biotic vegetation,
            creation of noise, dust and air pollution from handling of
            machinery, and increased risk of traffic accidents. These
            impacts are reversible, localized and satisfactory
            mitigation measures are in place.
